editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: DOCTOR LAST IN HIS CHARIOT: A COMEDY: As it is performed at the THEATRE ROYAL IN THE HAY-MARKET.
LONDON: Printed for W. GRIFFIN, at GARRICK's HEAD, in CATHARINE-STREET, STRAND. MDCCLXIX.

div.head: TO SAMUEL FOOTE, Eſq.
div.p: THO', had this comedy failed, which, from it's firſt night's reception, was ſomewhat more than probable, I ſhould certainly have ſuffered the whole diſgrace, it is not with leſs readineſs, that I ſeize this opportunity, on its better ſucceſs, to acknowledge the obligations which the editor of DOCTOR LAST IN HIS CHARIOT has to Mr. FOOTE.

I am indebted to you for undertaking a very long part; which, in your circumſtances, I conſider as a particular favour: I am indebted to you, for exerting unuſual ſpirit in the performance, when there was little hopes of putting the audience in a good humour; and more, (don't be aſhamed when I boaſt of it) I am indebted to you, not only for a whole ſcene, the conſultation of phyſicians in the firſt act, but for ſeveral hints throughout the piece, which had the happieſt effect, tho' ſome of them may, perhaps, have ſuffered by being cloathed in my language.

I am more particularly acknowledging upon this occaſion, becauſe, in the repeated remarks which the news-papers have
thought proper to make on your addreſs to the public, the firſt night this thing was acted, they would inſinuate, that you uſed the advantage your ſituation gave you, of a perſonal application to the audience, in order to throw contempt upon the piece while that and it's author were immediately under your protection.

However, Sir, while I return you thoſe thanks which, juſtice and gratitude oblige me to; I am extremely doubtful whether the public will conſider the favours I confeſs, as any capital exertion of benevolence on your part; for they will naturally ſay, that, as to your acting, the play could not poſſibly have done without it, which, after you had received it, muſt have been to your loſs; and, for giving me your wit and humour, all the world is ſenſible, that there is ſcarcely a man living who has ſo much to ſpare. I am,

closer.signed: Your moſt obliged humble ſervant, THE EDITOR.

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: THE following piece is a tranſlation of Le MALADE IMAGINAIRE, one of MOLIERE's moſt celebrated productions in the farcical kind. Some ſcenes which could not poſſibly ſucceed upon the Engliſh ſtage, have been removed, and thoſe ſubſtituted, in which the character of DOCTOR LAST is introduced; and, for that character only, the editor has to anſwer; nothing elſe in the ſubſequent ſcenes, being intirely his.

How it has hitherto appeared upon the ſtage, or how it may appear hereafter, is at preſent of little conſequence. It is ſubmitted to the candour of intelligent readers, who will conſider a farce as ſuch, and decide upon it's merit accordingly. To add more is needleſs, except thanks to the performers, particularly to Mr. Sowdon, for his kindneſs to the editor, when he ſtood in great need of aſſiſtance; and to that admirable comedian, Mr. Weſton, by whoſe excellent performance, Dr. Laſt is ſtill render'd a laughable object.

div.head: PROLOGUE,
div.byline: Written by D. GARRICK, Eſq. and ſpoken by Mr. FOOTE.
div.l: YOUR ſervants, kind maſters, from bottom to top.
Be aſſur'd, while I breath, or can walk—I mean hop,
Be you pleaſed to ſmile, or be pleaſed to grumble,
Be whatever you pleaſe, I am ſtill your moſt humble.
As to laugh is a right only given to man,
To keep up that right is my pride and my plan—
Fair ladies, don't frown, I meant woman too—
What's common to man, muſt be common to you.—
You all have a right your ſweet muſcles to curl,
From the old ſmirking prude, to the titt'ring young girl;
And ever with pleaſure my brains I could ſpin,
To make you all giggle, and you, ye gods, grin.
In this preſent ſummer, as well as the paſt,
To your favour again we preſent Dr. Laſt,
Who, by wonderful feats, in the papers recounted,
From trudging on foot, to his chariot has mounted.
Amongſt the old Britons, when war was begun,
Charioteers would ſlay ten, while the foot could ſlay one:
So, when doctors on wheels with diſpatches are ſent,
Mortality bills riſe a thouſand per cent.
But think not to phyſic that quack'ry's confin'd,
All the world is a ſtage, and the quacks are mankind—
There's trade, law, and ſtate-quacks; nay, would we but ſearch,
We ſhould find—Heaven bleſs us!—ſome quacks in the church!
The ſtiff band, and ſtiff bob of the methodiſt race,
Give the balſam of life and the tincture of grace,
And their poor wretched patients think much good is done 'em,
Tho' bliſters and cauſticks are ever upon them.
As for law and the ſtate, if quack'ry's a curſe,
Which will make the good bad, and the bad will make worſe,
We ſhould point out the quack, from the regular brother,
They are wiſer than I who can tell one from t'other!
Can the ſtage with its bills, puffs, and patents, ſtand trial,
Shall we find out no quacks in the Theatre Royal?
Some dramatical drugs that are puff'd on the town,
Cauſe many wry faces, and ſcarce will go down.
Nay, an audience ſometimes will in quack'ry delight,
And ſweat down an author ſome pounds in one night.
To return to our quack—ſhould he, help'd by the weather,
Raiſe laughter and kind perſpiration together,
Should his noſtrums of hips and of vapours but cure ye,
His chariot he well will deſerve, I aſſure ye.
'Tis eaſy to ſet up a chariot in town,
And eaſier ſtill is that chariot laid down.
He petitions by me, both as doctor and lover,
That you'll not ſtop his wheels, or his chariot tip over:
Fix him well, I beſeech you, the worſt on't would be,
Should you overturn him, you may overſet me.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: A Parlour in AILWOU'D's Houſe, with a Table and Chairs. PRUDENCE enters followed by WAG.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: WELL, but, Mrs. Prudence, don't be in a paſſion.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Mr. Wag, I will be in a paſſion; and it's enough to put any one in a paſſion to have to do with ſuch indiſcreet people as your maſter. I believe he's out of his ſenſes for my part.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: He's in love, Mrs. Prudence, and that's half way.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: So often as he has been forbid either to come or ſend after my miſtreſs, to perſiſt, in ſpite of all our cautions and interdictions—

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: He does not come or ſend, child.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: No—what do you do here then, and be hang'd to you?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I only bring a letter.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p:
Very pretty jeſting, truly. I was afraid that ſome of the family wou'd take notice of my
talking to you in the hall—But, in truth, here is no place of ſafety in the houſe; for now I've brought you up here, I'm afraid every moment of my maſter's ſurprizing us.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Does the old gentleman always keep the houſe then?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Keep the houſe!—he generally keeps his chamber, and very often his bed. You muſt know he's one of thoſe folks that are always ſick, continually complaining, ever taking phyſic, and, in reality, never ailing any thing. I'm his nurſe, with a plague to him, and he worries me out of my life.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Wou'd I were ſick upon the ſame conditions.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Come, come, no fooling.—You ſaid you had a letter from your maſter to my young lady: give it me, and I'll deliver it to her.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: There it is, my dear.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: But am not I a very naughty wench to be acceſſary, in this manner, to a clandeſtine correſpondence?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: The billet is perfectly innocent, I can aſſure you; and ſuch as your lady will read with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Well, now go away.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I won't, without you give me a kiſs.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Poh, you're a fool.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I won't, poz—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Then you may ſtay there all night.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Mrs. Prue—come.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Nay, if it's worth having, it's worth fetching.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Say you ſo, my girl—Thus, then, I approach thoſe charming lips. [Draws near her with ridiculous ceremony. A bell rings violently.]

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Confuſion! away, away, away, begone, as quick as you can, or we're both ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Ay! how! what the devil's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: My maſter's bell, my maſter's bell. He rings again! down the back ſtairs, and let yourſelf out at the ſtreet door. I can't ſtay to talk to you any longer now—adieu.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: [As he's going off.] Hey, what a ringing's here! one wou'd think the houſe was on fire.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: AILWOU'D, who comes thro' the Back Scene in a Night-Gown and Flannel Cap, his Crutch in one Hand, and a ſmall Bell in the other.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: O lord, O lord, here's uſage for a poor helpleſs ſick man! There's nobody in the houſe ſure; there can be nobody; they've all deſerted me, and left me alone to expire without aſſiſtance. I made ſhift to muſter up ſufficient ſtrength to crawl thus far; and now, I can die here. [Drops into the arm chair with a piteous groan; then, after a ſhort pauſe, ſtarting and ſtaring] Mercy on me, what's the matter with me! I'm ſuddenly ſeiz'd with a ſhivering fit!—And now I burn like a red-hot coal of fire!—And now again—ſhiver, ſhiver, ſhiver, as if my blood was turn'd into ſnow water!—Prudence, Nancy, Mrs. Ailwood, love, wife! they're all deaf! and my bell is not loud enough neither. Prudence,

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Here, Sir, here: what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ah, you jade, you ſlut.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: [Pretending to have hurt her head.] The deuce take your impatience; you hurry people ſo, you have made me break my head againſt the window-ſhutter.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: You baggage, you—'tis above an hour—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: [Crying.] Dear me, how it ſmarts!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Above an hour that I have been wanting ſomebody.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, huſſey, till I ſcold you.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Very pretty, in troth, after the blow I have got.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: You have left me to bawl and call till I'm hoarſe again.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: And you have made me get a great bump on my forehead; ſo put one againſt t'other and we're quit.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: How, Mrs. Impudence!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: If you ſcold, I'll cry.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: To deſert me in ſuch a manner!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: [Crying.] Oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Are you at it again?—Why, you pert, brazen, audacious, provoking, abominable, inſolent—Shan't I be allowed to have the pleaſure of finding fault with you?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: You may have that pleaſure, if you will; and it's as fair that I ſhou'd have the pleaſure of crying, if I like it.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, well, have done.—Take away theſe things, and get me my medicine. It's three hours and two minutes ſince I took it; and don't you know the preſcription ſays every three hours? I feel the bad effects of my omiſſion already.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, why will you drench yourſelf with ſuch naſty ſlops? One wou'd think the phyſicians and apothecaries cou'd find ſufficient ſtuff for your craving bowels; but you muſt go to the quacks too; and this Doctor Laſt, with his univerſal balſamic reſtorative cordial, that turns water into aſſes milk.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: That's a good girl, go on.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Methinks if one was to take phyſic, one wou'd rather chuſe to go to a regular phyſician than to a quack.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And why ſo, my dainty adviſer?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: For the ſame reaſon that, if I wanted a pair of ſhoes, I wou'd rather go to an eſtabliſhed ſhoemaker, than lay out my money at a Yorkſhire warehouſe.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: If I hear any more of your impudence, I'll break your head to ſome purpoſe, it ſhan't be a bump in the forehead will ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Eh, you old fanciful, fooliſh—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Go and call my daughter Nancy to me, I have ſomething to ſay to her.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: She's here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Come here, Nancy; I want to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What's your pleaſure, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Stay; before I ſay or do any thing further, I'll go into the next room and take my medicine—I ſhou'd be a great fool to forget that.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, ſo you wou'd.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I ſhould, indeed, for it does me a prodigious deal of good; though I muſt take a little cooling phyſick too, in order to correct the juices.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Look on me a little.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Well, I do look on you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Well, what wou'd you have with Prudence?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Can't you gueſs?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Some diſcourſe, I ſuppoſe, about our new acquaintance, Mr. Hargrave; for you have done nothing but talk of him for this week paſt.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And can you blame me for the good opinion I have of him?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Who ſays I do?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Or would you have me inſenſible to the tender proteſtations which he makes me?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Heav'n forbid.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Pr'ythee tell me now, Prudence, don't you really think there was ſomething of deſtiny in the odd adventure that brought us acquainted?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Was there not ſomething uncommonly brave and gentleman-like in that action of reſcuing me without knowing any thing of me?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Very genteel and gentleman-like, indeed.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And was it poſſible for any one to make a more generous uſe of it?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Then, Prue, he has a moſt charming perſon.—Don't you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Who can think otherwiſe?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Something very noble in his air?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Very noble.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Then he talks like an angel.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Ay, and writes like an angel too, I dare ſwear, ma'am; as this letter will ſhew.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: From Mr. Hargrave! You wicked girl, why wou'd you keep it from me ſo long? [Snatches it from her and reads it to herſelf.]

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Well, ma'am, what does the gentleman ſay?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Every thing, dear Prue; every thing in the world that I cou'd wiſh or deſire. He ſays he can't live happy without me, and that he will, by the means of a common friend, immediately make a formal propoſal for me to my father.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: But do you think, ma'am, that your father will liſten?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: He can have no objection, Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p:
No, ma'am. But your mother-in-law may, who governs him, and, I'm ſure, bears
you no good will. The beſt joke is, ſhe thinks ſhe has wheedled me into her intereſts—

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Huſh! here's my father.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Nancy child, I have a piece of news to tell you, that, perhaps, you little expect. Here's a match propos'd to me for you. You ſmile at that! Ah, nature, nature! By what I perceive then, I need not aſk you if you are willing?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I am ready to ſubmit to your commands in every thing, Sir.—Dear Prue, this is beyond my hopes.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Mr. Hargrave has kept his word, madam.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: What are you whiſpering about?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir,

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, child, at any rate I am glad to find you in ſo complying a diſpoſition: for, to tell you the truth, I was reſolved on the thing before I mentioned it to you, and had even given my word to put it as expeditiouſly as poſſible into execution.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I am ſure you are very much in the right of it, Sir; it's the wiſeſt thing you ever did in your life.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I have not ſeen the gentleman yet, but I am told he will be every way to the ſatisfaction of us both.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: That, Sir, I am certain of, for I have ſeen him already.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Have you?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Since your conſent, Sir, encourages me to diſcover my inclinations, you muſt know that good fortune has lately brought us acquainted; and, that the propoſal which has been made to you is the effect of that eſteem which, at the firſt interview, we conceived for one another.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: That's more than I knew, but no matter; the ſmoother things go on the better I am pleaſed.—He is but a little man I am told.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: He's well made, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Agreeable in his perſon?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Very agreeable.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: In his addreſs?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Perfectly elegant.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Really that's much—Very much upon my word, that a man of low birth, and bred up to a mean profeſſion—for, tho' the doctor has now fifteen thouſand pounds in the funds, and gets eight or nine hundred a year, he owes all to his medicinal ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: At leaſt ſo Mr. Traſh, the bookſeller that vends his medicines, tells me; thro' whoſe mediation, indeed, this propoſal is made.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Mr. Traſh! Has Mr. Hargrave any thing to do then—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Hargrave! who the devil's he? I am talking of the perſon you are to marry, Dr. Laſt, whoſe cordial has done me ſo much ſervice. It ſeems he is a widower, and has a mind to get a ſecond wife that may do him ſome credit; ſuch as his worldly circumſtances intitle him to.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Well, but my dear Sir—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p:
Yes, child, I know it's very well—The doctor is to be brought here to-day to be introduced
to me, and I am really concern'd that I appointed Dr. Coffin, Dr. Skeleton, and Dr. Bulruddery, to hold a conſultation upon my caſe this morning; for I have found ſo much benefit from Dr. Laſt's medicine, that I think he will be the propereſt perſon to find out what's the matter with me.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Well but, Sir, give me leave to tell you that Dr. Laſt was very far from my thoughts when we began this converſation. In ſhort, papa, all this while you have been talking of one perſon and I of another.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Poh, poh, madam, make yourſelf eaſy, my maſter can have no ſuch ridiculous deſign as he has been mentioning to you—Marry a young lady of family and fortune to a ſcoundrel quack!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And what buſineſs have you to be meddling, impudence?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: No buſineſs at all, Sir—But, if you are really ſerious in your deſign about this marriage, give me leave to aſk you, what can have put it into your head?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: You have nothing to do with that—I have told the girl the party I propoſe for her is rich; but, if you muſt know what moſt inclin'd, and, indeed, determin'd me, as it were, to accept of Dr. Laſt for a ſon-in-law, is the number of invaluable ſecrets he poſſeſſes; and this alliance will intitle me to take his medicines gratis, as my various infirmities may require—a thing that we ought all to conſider, my laſt year's apothecary's bill amounting to two hundred and nineteen pounds, four ſhillings and eleven pence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: A very pretty reaſon for marrying your daughter to a quack indeed!—But, after all, Sir, tell me, upon your honour, now, does any thing ail you?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Eh! how! any thing ail me!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Ay Sir, are you ſick in earneſt; and, if ſo, what's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: It's my misfortune not to know—wou'd to Heav'n I did. But, to cut ſhort all theſe impertinences, look you, daughter, I lay my commands upon you to prepare yourſelf to receive the huſband I propoſe for you.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: And I, madam, on my part, command you to have nothing to do with him. [going off.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why, you impudent ſlut, ſhall a chambermaid take the liberty—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: She ſhan't marry the quack.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Shan't ſhe! we'll ſee that, if I get near enough to lay my cane acroſs your ſhoulders. [Riſing in a fury.]

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dear Sir—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh, don't hinder him, madam; give him leave to come; he's welcome to do his worſt.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: If I lay hold of you— [Following her.]

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I ſay I won't let you do a fooliſh thing if I can help it. [Getting behind a chair.]

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Come hither, come hither, [ſtill following her.] Nancy, ſtop her there, don't let her paſs.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I believe no father but yourſelf ever thought of ſuch a thing.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Help me to catch her, daughter, or I'll never give you my bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Never mind him, madam.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: An audacious, impudent, inſolent—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you may abuſe me if you pleaſe; but I won't give my conſent to the match for all that.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Cockatrice, jade, ſlut. [Chaſing her round the ſtage.] Oh, oh, I can ſupport no longer, ſhe has kill'd, ſhe has murder'd me. Falls into his chair.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Your humble ſervant, ſweet Sir—Come away, madam.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Love! Wife! Mrs. Ailwou'd!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: How now!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Oh, lamb, lamb, come hither if you love me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: What's the matter with my poor dear?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Help me, ſweeteſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: I will help thee; what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Lamb!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Well, my heart?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: They have been teazing and fretting me here out of the ſmall portion of life and ſpirit I have left.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: No, ſweet, I hope not. Who has anger'd thee?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: That jade Prudence—She is grown more ſaucy and impudent than ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Don't put yourſelf in a paſſion with her, my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Ail
sp.p: I don't believe I ſhall ever recover it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Yes, yes, compoſe yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: She has been contradicting me—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Don't mind her.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And has had the impudence to tell me I'm not ſick, when you know, my lamb, how it is with me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: I know, my heart, very well, you are feeble and weak—Heav'n help thee!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: That jade will bring me to my grave. She is the cauſe of half the phlegm I breed; and I have deſir'd, a hundred and a hundred times, that you wou'd turn her off.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: My child, there are no ſervants but have their faults, and we muſt endure their bad qualities, that we may have the uſe of their good ones. However, I will give Mrs. Prudence a lecture for her impertinence, I aſſure you—Who's there? Prue, Prudence, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Did you call me, madam? [very demurely].

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Come hither, miſtreſs—What is the meaning that you fret and thwart your maſter, and put him into paſſions?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Who, I, madam! Bleſs my ſoul, I don't know what you mean: I'm ſure, my ſtudy, morning, noon and night, is how to pleaſe and obey him.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Don't believe her, my dear; ſhe's a liar; ſhe neither pleaſes nor obeys me, and has behaved in the moſt inſolent manner.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Well, my ſoul, I'm ſure what you ſay is right; but compoſe yourſelf.—Look you, Prudence, if ever you provoke your maſter again, I'll turn you out of doors.—Here give me his pillows, and help me to ſettle him in his chair—He ſits I know not how—Pull your night-cap over your ears, my dear. There's nothing gives people cold ſo much as letting wind in at their ears.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ah, my love, I ſhall never be able to repay all the care you take of me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Raiſe yourſelf a little, that I may put this under you—this behind your back—and this to lean your head upon.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: And this to comfort your brains. [Claps a pillow rudely on his head.]

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: You curſed jade, do you want to ſtifle me? [Gets up in a paſſion, throws the pillows at her, and drives her out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Hold, hold, what did ſhe do to you?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Do to me! the ſerpent.—She'll be the death of me if you continue to keep her in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Well but, jewel, you are too apt to flurry yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: My ſweet, you are the only comfort I have; and, in order to requite your tenderneſs, in the beſt manner I am able, I have reſolv'd, as I have told you, to make my will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Ah, don't talk to me in that manner, don't, Mr. Ailwou'd, I beſeech you, unleſs you have a mind to break my heart.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Alas, my love, we are all mortal; but don't cry, Biddy, for you'll make me weep too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Nay, deareſt—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: You ſaid ſomething of your will, did'n't you?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I deſir'd you wou'd ſpeak to your attorney about it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Yes; but I cannot ſpeak to him about any ſuch thing; it wou'd cut me to the heart.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: It muſt be done, Biddy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: No, no, no.—However, I have deſired him to come hither to-day, and you may ſpeak to him about it yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I wou'd fain be inform'd in what manner I may cut off my children, and leave all to you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Alas, my dear, if you ſhou'd be taken away, I'll ſtay no longer in the world.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: My only concern, when I die, will be that I never had a child by you; and Dr. Bulruddery, the Iriſh phyſician, promis'd me I ſhould have twins.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: But do you think, my dear, that you will be able to cut off your two daughters and leave me all?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: If not my landed eſtate, at any rate I can leave you my ready money; and, by way of precaution, I will make over to you immediately, four thouſand pounds which I have in the three per cents, and bonds for near the ſame ſum, which I lent to Sir Timothy Whiſky.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: I will have nothing to do with them indeed, Mr. Ailwou'd; you ſhan't put them into my hands I aſſure you; all the riches in the world will be nothing to me if I loſe you.—How much do you ſay you have in the three per cents?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Four thouſand pounds, my love.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: To talk to me of money when I am depriv'd of the only perſon with whom I cou'd enjoy it!—And how much more in bonds?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: About the ſame ſum, ſweet—but don't take on ſo Biddy, pray now don't, you'll throw yourſelf into ſome illneſs; and to have us both ſick—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Sir, there are the three doctors below, in the parlour, that were to call upon you this morning.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay, they are come to conſult upon my caſe. I'm ſorry I ſpoke to them, but it's too late now.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: And there's another gentleman at the door, in a chariot, with Mr. Traſh, the bookſeller, who deſir'd me to tell you he had brought Doctor Laſt.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I hope the gentlemen in the parlour did not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: No, Sir, no.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Very well, then ſhew the phyſician's up.—Do you, my love, go and entertain Dr. Laſt till I can come to you.—I will diſpatch theſe as ſoon as I can, but one muſt keep up the forms of civility.

div.head: SCENE XI.
div.stage: AILWOU'D, Dr. COFFIN, Dr. SKELETON, Dr. BULRUDDERY.

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: Mr. Ailwou'd, your ſervant. I have obey'd your commands, you ſee; and am come, with my brothers Skeleton and Bulruddery, to have a conſultation upon your caſe.—How do you find yourſelf this morning?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Pray, gentlemen, beſeated.—Why, really, doctor, I find myſelf but very indifferent.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: How do you ſleep, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Very indifferently, doctor; chiefly broken ſlumbers.

sp.speaker: Bulrud.
sp.p: And pray, how is your appetite?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Indifferent, very indifferent, indeed. I made ſhift to get down a couple of diſhes of chocolate this morning in bed; about two hours after I had ſome tea and toaſt with my wife; juſt now I ſwallow'd, with much difficulty, a baſon of ſoup; and I believe I ſhall hardly take any thing more till dinner.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: But, Mr. Ailwou'd, what are your chief complaints?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p:
Really, doctor, I am afraid my diſorder is a complication. Sometimes I think it is the gout, ſometimes the rheumatiſm, ſometimes the dropſy, and ſometimes I feel myſelf in a high fever: however, gentlemen, Doctor Coffin here has been long my good friend and phyſician, and, by the help of the intelligence he can give you about my conſtitution, your art and experience may perhaps enable you to find out what's
the matter with me; ſo I leave you to your conſultation. Gentlemen your ſervant. [Ailwou'd feeing the doctors as he goes out, drops a guinea.] Stay, doctor, I'll take it up for you.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you;—but, I think, there was another dropt?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: No, there was'nt—

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: Why,—I have but two.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: But two!—Oh! hoh! (gives him another.)

div.head: SCENE XII.
div.stage: Dr. COFFIN, Dr. SKELETON, Dr. BULRUDDERY, ſitting down with great ceremony; then, after a ſhort ſilence,

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: Brother Coffin, ſhall I trouble you for a pinch of your— (taking ſnuff) Havannah, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Coff
sp.p: Brought me from thence by a captain, who aſſiſted in taking the place.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: (Sneezes) Deviliſh ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Bulrud.
sp.p: I have often, Dr. Skeleton, had it in my head to aſk ſome of the faculty, what can be the reaſon that when a man happens to ſneeze all the company bows?

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: Sneezing, Dr. Bulruddery, was a mortal ſymptom that attended a peſtilential diſeaſe, which formerly depopulated the republic of Athens; ever ſince, when that convulſion occurs, a ſhort ejaculation is offered up, that the ſneezing or ſternuting party, may not be afflicted with the ſame diſtemper.

sp.speaker: Bulrud.
sp.p:
Upon my conſcience, a very learned account! ay, and a very civil inſtitution too. I can't help thinking, doctor, but the gentlemen
of our profeſſion muſt arrive much better in them there foreign parts, than at home: now, becauſe why, one hears of plagues and peſtilences, and ſuch like kind of diſorders that attack a whole nation at once. Now, here, you know, we are obliged to pick up patients one by one, juſt as a body can get them.

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: Ay, doctor; and, ſince the great increaſe of this town, the ſick lie ſo ſcattered, that one pair of horſes are ſcarce ſufficient for a phyſician but in moderate practice.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: True; why, there was yeſterday, the firſt pulſe I felt belonged to a lad with the meaſles, in Dean's-yard, Weſtminſter: from thence I ſet out between ſeven and eight, my wig freſh powdered, and my horſes in ſpirits; I turned at Charing Croſs for the New Buildings; then run through the Holbourn diviſion, croſſed the Fleet-market, and penetrated into the city as far as Whitechapel; then, made a ſhort trip to the wife of a ſaleſman, who had the gout in her ſtomach, at Wapping; from thence, returned through Cornhill, Temple-Bar, and the Strand, and finiſhed my laſt preſcription, between five and ſix, for a tradeſman in Cockſpur-ſtreet, who had burſt a vein in hallooing at the Brentford election.

sp.speaker: Bulrud.
sp.p: Upon my conſcience, a long tour.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: Long! Why, upon the moſt moderate calculation, I could not, before I ſat down to my ſoup, have run up leſs than thirty pair of ſtairs; and my horſes muſt have trotted, taking in croſs-ſtreets and turnings, at leaſt, eighteen miles and three quarters.

sp.speaker: Bulrud.
sp.p:
Without doubt. But you was talking of Brentford.—Don't you look upon a conteſted
election as a good thing to the faculty, doctor?

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: If you mean to us of the college, Dr. Bulruddery, little or nothing: if, indeed, there ſhould happen to be warm work at the huſtings, the corporation of ſurgeons may pick up ſome practice, tho' I don't look upon any of theſe public tranſactions as of any great uſe to our body, in general. Lord-mayor's day, indeed, has its merit.

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: Yes; that turns to account.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: Dr. Doſeum and I, were making, t'other morning, at Batſon's, a ſhort calculation of what value that feſtival might be to the whole phyſical tribe.

sp.speaker: Bulrud.
sp.p: Is it a ſecret to what you made it amount?

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: Why; what with colds caught on the water before dinner, repletion and indigeſtion at dinner, inebriety after dinner, (not to mention the ball in the evening) we made that day, and its conſequences, for you know, there are fine foundations laid for future diſorders, eſpecially if it turns out an eaſterly wind.—

sp.speaker: Bulrud.
sp.p: Does that make any great difference?

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: Infinite;—for when they come out of the hall, in a fine perſpiration, from the heat of the room, and exerciſe, ſhould the wind miſs them in croſſing Cateaton-ſtreet, its ſure to lay hold of them in turning the corner into Cheapfide.—

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: Without doubt.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: We eſtimated the whole profit to phyſicians, ſurgeons, apothecaries, chymiſts, druggiſts, and nurſes, at eleven thouſand ſix hundred ſeventy-three pounds fourteen ſhillings and three-pence three farthings.

div.head: SCENE XIII.
div.stage: Dr. COFFIN, Dr. SKELETON, Dr. BULRUDDERY, and AILWOU'D.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I beg pardon for this interruption; but you have been conſulting upon my caſe, and I have ſome particular reaſons for coming thus ſuddenly, to deſire to know what opinion you have yet been able to form?

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: (To Skeleton.) Come, Sir.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: No, Sir; pray do you ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: Before my ſenior! pray excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: (To Bulruddery.) Doctor—

sp.speaker: Bulrud.
sp.p: The devil burn myſelf if I do.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Nay; pray, gentlemen, leave theſe ceremonies; and, if you have been able to form any opinion—inſtruct me.

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: Why, really Sir, to tell you the truth—Brother Skeleton.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: We have not yet, with all the obſervations we have been able to make upon your caſe and complaints—I ſay, Sir,—and, after the moſt abſtruſe diſquiſitions, we have not as yet been able—to form any opinion at all.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, this is all I want to be acquainted with; becauſe, if you have not been able to form any opinion, I have been happy enough to meet with a phyſician that has.—Pray, Sir, do me the favour to walk in here.

div.head: SCENE XIV.
div.stage: Dr. COFFIN, Dr. SKELETON, Dr. BULRUDDERY, AILWOU'D, Dr. LAST.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: This, gentlemen, is Dr. Laſt; and he aſſures me, that my diſorder is a confirmed jaundice.

sp.speaker: Doctors.
sp.p: A jaundice!—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: What do you grin at?—I ſays, he has the janders, and I'll uphold it.—I'll lay you fifty pound he has the janders, and the gentleman ſhall hold the ſtakes himſelf.

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: Well, but, Mr. Ailwou'd, this is altogether ridiculous. Did you ever ſee a man of your colour with the jaundice?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why, that's true; (turning to Laſt) every one tells me that I have a very florid complexion; now, the jaundice gives a yellow hue: will you be ſo good as to explain that?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Well, ſo I can, but not for the doctors.—If I does it, its all intirely to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: We ſhall hear how the impudent raſcal will bring himſelf off.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: There are two ſorts of janders; the yallar, and the grey.

sp.speaker: Bulrud.
sp.p: The black, I believe, you mean, honey.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: No, I don't.

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: But you muſt, Sir; there is no ſuch thing as the grey jaundice.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: Oh! gentlemen, the doctor means the iron-grey, and that's almoſt black, you know.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: They only does this to put me out now, becauſe I'm no collegian.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, pray, doctor, go on with your explanation.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Well, I ſays then; (To Ailwou'd, who turns about for ſomething) I won't talk without you minds;—the yallar janders, I ſay, is,—the yallar janders is, as if ſo be—

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: Why, you were talking of the grey jaundice this moment.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: No I was'nt, I did'nt ſay a word of the grey janders.—Did I, Mr. Ailwood?—It's the yallar janders.—I knows well enough what I'm about, if you'll let me alone.

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: Well, what of the yallar janders?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Why, I won't tell you.—I won't ſay a word more now; if you thinks to profit you're miſtaken; you ſhan't learn nothing from me.

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: You're a bloody impudent fellow.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: I does my cures no purchaſe no pay; and which of you can ſay that?— (turning to Ailwou'd.) Many a one of them comes to ax my advice and aſſiſtance, when they don't know what to do themſelves.

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: Come, come, friend, we know you.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Well, and I knows you.—Pray, Dr. Coffin, did'n't you attend one Mrs. Greaves, a tallow chandler's widow, that lodg'd at the pork ſhop in Fetter-lane; and didn't ſhe ſend for me after you gave her over?

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: Yes; and ſhe died in two days.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Well,—ſo ſhe did;—but that was no fault of mine, ſhe ſhou'd have ſent for me firſt. What cou'd I do for her, after you had kill'd the poor dear ſoul?

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: But, Mr. Ailwou'd, we are come here to conſult upon your caſe; and if you permit us, we are willing.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: O! nothing I deſire ſo much; and to aſſiſt you, I'll leave this gentleman; he may give you further reaſons for what he advances.

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: What, Sir, do you think we'll conſult with a quack?

sp.speaker: Bulrud.
sp.p: Ay, do you think we'll be after conſulting with a quack?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: I'm no quack.—I have been regularly ſubmitted, and I'll perſecute you for your words in Weſtminſter-hall.

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: Mr. Ailwood, we are your humble ſervants.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, but, gentlemen, your fees; you'll return them, I hope.

sp.speaker: Coff.
sp.p: Return our fees, Sir!—

sp.speaker: Bulrud.
sp.p: Return our fees! Arrah, is the man mad?

sp.speaker: Skel.
sp.p: Sir, it is a thing entirely out of the courſe of practice. We wiſh you a good morning.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why then, gentlemen, your ſervant, and good morning to you. Let them go, I'm glad we have got rid of them at any rate.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Here, you Coffin—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Pray let them alone now.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: I would ſend him a challenge, if I was not afraid of being committed.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: A challenge! Why, did you ever fight?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Yes; I had like to be killed two or three times, but I never was.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: It was very well for me, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: You muſt think they all hates me, becauſe I out-does 'em in curing, and they are oſtentatious in their own way, and won't be larn'd.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And ſo, doctor, you are really of opinion that I have a diſpoſition to the jaundice?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Yes, you have, and its one of the ſix and twenty diſorders ſpecified in my advertiſement; and I challenge all England to do the like, to cure ſix and twenty diſorders with one medicine, without confinement, or hinderance of buſineſs, or knowledge of a bedfellow. You underſtand me, for that's in it too, if you have any remains lurking in your blood from bad treatment.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: No, no; Heaven be thank'd, I never had any ſuch thing in my life.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: So much the better for you; but if you had, I could ſoon ſet you to rights again.—Why, there was three affidavys in the paper as laſt Wedneſday, acknowledging benefits receiv'd from me; one from a journeyman taylor, bed-rid with the rheumatiſs; another, from a hackney-coachman, that had been three times tap'd for the dropſey; and one from a child's mother that I cur'd of the dry gripes.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, doctor, if you will now come into the next room, I will introduce you to my daughter.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: What! In this trim? I would not for fifty guineas—beſides, I'm going to ſee a gentlewoman that I've got in hand for an impoſtor;—but I'll tell you what I'll do—I'll dreſs myſelf, and come to you in the evening.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, do ſo then, if it be more convenient to you;—but ſtay, doctor, your paper of directions orders your medicine to be taken only every three hours; now, as I have ſome ſpare time on my hands, ſuppoſe I was to take in the intervals, a mug or two of the Dog and Duck water, or Iſlington Spa, or Bagnige-wells, by way of diluting.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: You muſtn't take nothing by way of diſſolution, but a few broth made with vermin's jelly.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Have you any objection then to my going to Chelſea, to be fumigated at Dominicetti's?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Domini Devil's! don't go near him. Is it to be ſweated you wants? If that be all, I can ſweat you myſelf. Do you chuſe to be ſweated?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why, if I thought it wou'd do me any good.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Well, I'll conſider of it;—but, remember, Mr. Ailwou'd, I have taken you in hand now, and if you go to be purged, or puked, or buy a ſup of phyſic from any one elſe;—but, I ſuppoſe, you knows better what belongs to the charakter of a gentleman?

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.
div.stage: Another Room in AILWOU'D's Houſe. PRUDENCE enters followed by HARGRAVE.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p: COME, Sir, follow me, I'll venture to bring you in, ſince you've ventur'd to knock at the door.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But tell me, my beſt girl, cannot you contrive to make me happy in the ſight of your charming miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: No, Mr. Hargrave, I cannot, indeed; you have been told ſo a thouſand times already: I ſent you word ſo by your ſervant this morning, but you won't be ſatisfied; and, as if you had not been imprudent enough already, you are now come here in perſon, to put the finiſhing ſtroke to our ruin.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, my good Prue, I was aware of that, and am not come here in my own character, but as a friend of your young lady's Italian maſter, who has given me leave to ſay he has ſent me in his place.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: That's more forecaſt than I thought you capable of—But, why have you been ſo negligent; did not you tell my miſtreſs, that you wou'd make a formal propoſal to her father?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: True—Nor is it my fault that it has not been done; I ſpoke to Mr. Friendly, Mr. Ailwou'd's brother-in-law, who aſſur'd me he wou'd make it his buſineſs to come here this day for that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p:
Ay; but this day is too late, it ſhou'd have been done yeſterday: for now her father
is going to marry her to another perſon—A raſcal quack—Tho', I think, if we cou'd ſet my maſter againſt him, which wou'd be no very hard matter—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I don't know any method ſo ſure, as by the help of another quack; for he falls in love with every new medicine he hears of.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Say you ſo? Gad, I have a good comical fellow for my ſervant, and there is a thought come into my head—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Huſh! here's my maſter; ſtep into the next room a little, while I prepare him for your reception.

sp.speaker: Ail
sp.p: Dr. Laſt directed me, during the operation of his medicine, to take ten or twelve turns about the room; but I forgot to aſk him whether it wou'd be moſt efficacious, the long way, or the broad—I wiſh I had aſk'd him that.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Sir, here is a—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Speak low huſſey; you are enough to ſhock my brains—You don't conſider, that it is not fit to bawl in the ears of ſick people.

sp.speaker: Hru.
sp.p: I was going to tell you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Speak low, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Sir. (Speaks ſo low as not to be heard.)

sp.speaker: Ail
sp.p: Eh!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I was going to tell you— (very low.)

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: What is it you ſay?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: (Very loud.) I ſay, here's a man without wants to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, you devil, let him come in.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: [As loud as ſhe can bawl.] Come in, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Oh, my head, my head!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Mr. Ailwou'd—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Don't ſpeak ſo loud, for fear of ſhocking my maſter's brains.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I am very glad to find you out of bed, and to ſee that you grow better.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: What do you mean by growing better?—it's falſe, my maſter's always very ill.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I don't know how that may be—but I was told he was better; and I think he looks pretty well.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Poh, you're blind, he look's as bad as poſſible; and they are impertinent people, that ſay he mends: he grows worſe and worſe.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: She's in the right of it.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: He walks, eats, and drinks like other men; but, that's no reaſon why he ſhou'd not be in a bad ſtate of health.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: 'Tis very true.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I can only ſay then, Sir, that I am extremely ſorry for your indiſpoſition; and hope you will ſoon get the better of it.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And, now compliments are paſt, Sir—Pray may I take the liberty to deſire to know who you are?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
Sir, I come here on the part of Miſs Ailwou'd's Italian maſter; who is gone for ſome time into the country, and ſends me, being his
intimate friend, to continue her leſſons, leſt, by interrupting them, ſhe ſhou'd forget what ſhe has already learn'd.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Very well; call Nancy.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I believe, Sir, it will be better to take the gentleman into her chamber.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: No, let her come here.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: He can't give her her leſſon ſo well, if he is not alone with her.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Beſides, it will only diſturb you in the condition you are in, to have people talking in the room.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Leave that to me—Here is my daughter.—Rot you, get out of my ſight, and let me know when Dr. Laſt comes.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Nancy my dear, your Italian maſter is gone into the country, and has ſent a gentleman to teach you in his room.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Oh, heaven's!—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: What's the matter? Why this aſtoniſhment?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Becauſe, papa—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Becauſe, what?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, the moſt ſurprizing thing happens here!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: So it ſeems, indeed.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p:
I dream't laſt night, papa, that I was in a crowd coming out of a play-houſe, where a rude fellow attempted to lay hold of me; when
a gentleman, exactly like this, came to my aſſiſtance, and reſcu'd me from the ruffian's hands; and I am ſo ſurpriz'd, papa, to ſee before me the very ſame perſon I fancy'd in my dream—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Did you ever hear ſuch an idiot as it is?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I count myſelf extremely fortunate, madam, to have employ'd your thoughts either ſleeping or waking; and ſhou'd eſteem myſelf particularly happy, to relieve you from any diſtreſs which accident might throw you into: for, I aſſure you, madam—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why, now, Sir, you are rather more fooliſh than ſhe—But, pray have done with your nonſenſe, both the one and other; and you, Sir, if you pleaſe, give the girl her leſſon.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You know, ma'am, a great man formerly ſaid, that if he ſpoke to the Gods, he wou'd ſpeak Spaniſh; to men, French; but to women, Italian, as the propereſt language for love.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: A ſtrange round-a-bout way of beginning.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: If he was to ſpeak to his horſe, indeed, he ſaid he wou'd ſpeak in High Dutch; as for example, Das dick der donder ſchalq.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: So, you won't have done fooling.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, give me leave; every maſter has his method—No doubt, madam, you have been inform'd, that the adjective muſt agree with the ſubſtantive, as thus—Nanetta bella, beautiful Nancy, [ſoftly to her] that is you my charmer—Amante fidele, Faithful lover [ſoftly to her] That's me my charmer, who doat upon you more than life. [Ailwou'd coming cloſe to liſten, Hargrave raiſes his voice.] Now theſe, ma'am, muſt agree in gender, number, and caſe.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay, that's right enough; I remember that when I was learning grammar myſelf.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Come, madam, we'll take a verb active, and begin if you pleaſe, with Amo, to love—Have you any objection to that?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: By no means, Sir.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Then pray give a little attention, and conjugate after me, that you may catch the accent—Io amo, I love.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Io amo, I love.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: O fy! that's not a proper tone.—You'll pardon me for reprimanding miſs before you.—you muſt pronounce the words with more tenderneſs, ma'am: take notice of me—Io amo, I love.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (Very tenderly) Io amo, I love.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I won't have her pronounce it any more; I don't know what words you'll have the impudence to teach her preſently.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Might I ſpeak with you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Speak with me!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: If it won't diſturb you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: A curſe light on you, what is it you want?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: To tell you ſomething, Sir, if you won't ſly in a paſſion.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, tell it.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, one does not know how to take you, you really frighten me out of my wits.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: She won't ſpeak now.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I—will ſpeak (altering her tone) there's doctor Laſt below as fine as a mounta-bank.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Daughter go into your chamber; and I muſt beg of you, Sir, to take your leave; and pray let your friend know, that neither he, nor his ſubſtitue, need continue their viſits for the future.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: [Aſide] Well, my good old gentleman, you ſhall hear from me again ſooner than you imagine; for, ſince the way has been pointed out to me, I will make a bold puſh to drive this quack out of the houſe.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: AILWOU'D, PRUDENCE, and DOCTOR LAST, dreſt in a tawdry manner, follow'd by a black boy.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: An impudent raſcal has thrown a dead cat into my chariot, and hit me ſuch a douſe on the noſe, beſides ſplaſhing me!—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Doctor Laſt—

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Mr. Ailwou'd—Sir, I pay you my compliments—Pompey bring the carriage for me at ſix o'clock—and, d'ye hear, call at Coven-Garden market for the yerbs, and put them into the boot.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Upon my word! (admiring Laſt) Lord, Lord, what an advantage dreſs is!

sp.speaker: Dr. Laſt.
sp.p: To tell you the truth, I got this ſuit of cloaths a bargain: they belong'd to a gentleman as died under my hands.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Prudence, go and deſire your young miſtreſs to come hither.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Dr. Laſt—Sir, your moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: You impudent, ſaucy—

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Never mind her; Lord, ſhe meant no harm—I'm too good natur'd to take notice of every trifle—I'm one of the beſt naturd'ſt little fellows, I believe, that ever was born—Why I'm like a dog in my own houſe; I never troubles myſelf about nothing; all I deſire is to ſee things handſome, and they give me whatever they pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, I think my daughter will, in that reſpect, match you to a tittle, for ſhe's as good natur'd a girl as lives.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: I'll tell you a thing you'll be glad to hear—I believe I ſhall come out with a new medicine in a day or two.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I'll take it—What is it?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Eſſence of cucumber.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Of cucumber!

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Ay, for the heartburn.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I'm very often troubl'd with that diſorder; but will it be good for nothing elſe?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Yes, it will be good for the cramp.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I've had an odd pain in the ball of my foot all day, I don't know what it may turn to.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p:
I wiſh miſs Nancy wou'd come, for I think we ſhou'd prove agreeable, and we'd fix
things directly; I'll ſettle whatever you pleaſe upon her, for I've neither chick nor child but my old mother.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Here ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Nancy, this is Dr. Laſt.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: No offence miſs, I hope (goes up and kiſſes her) I thinks, Mr. Ailwou'd, ſhe's very much like you, only ſhe wants a ſcrap of colour, but I'll give her a bottle of ſtuff when we're married, that in three doſes will make her cheeks as red as a roſe.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why don't you ſpeak to the Dr. Nancy?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I don't know what to ſay, Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Let her alone, let her alone; we'll talk faſt enough when we're better acquainted—I fancy, Mr. Ailwou'd, we ſhall have very fine children; I had three as beautiful babes, by my laſt ſpouſe, as ever a woman brought into the world.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I hope they're dead doctor.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I told you ſo a bit a gone. Sweet pretty little angels, they all lies in Pancridge church-yard, with their poor dear mammy.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: In Pancras church-yard!

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Yes, there's tomb-ſtones over every one of them.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Tomb-ſtones!

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Is there tho'?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Yes; what's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Heigh ho.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Have you got the cholic?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Has any ſudden illneſs ſeiz'd you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: No, only low ſpirits. I think, ſome-how, I ſhall be buried in Pancras church-yard myſelf.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, how can you take ſuch things into your head?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I wiſh there had been no talk about tombſtones

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Here's my lady.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: Dr. LAST, Mrs. AILWOU'D, AILWOU'D, PRUDENCE, NANCY.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Mrs. Ailwou'd, this is Dr. Laſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: I have ſeen the doctor before, my dear; but what's the matter with you, eh?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Nothing, madam, nothing; he has only got a little fit of the horrors; let him alone, he'll come to himſelf again by and bye.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: I hope, daughter-in-law, you are ſenſible of the goodneſs of this gentleman, in taking you without a portion.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and I hope my parſon proves agreeable to her. Have you ſeen my picture, miſs, that's in the expedition room at Spring Gardens?—every one ſays it's monſtrous like me. Take her to ſee it, do, it will coſt but a ſhilling; you'll eaſily know it; it's o'the ſame ſide with the image there—Venus the methodiſt, I thinks, they calls it.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, but, doctor, give me leave to aſk you, and don't be offended at my being a little particular, on account of my girl; I know you have realiz'd ſomething conſiderable; but, how have you laid out your money? Have you ever a ſcrap of land?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Why, as far as this here, there's my place by Hounſlow, I bought it out and out, the whole concern coſtis me upwards of fifteen hundred pounds, with my pond and my pigeon houſe, and—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Have you any fiſh in your pond, doctor?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: No, my dear, it's not deep enough; beſides, it's in the road, and I'm afraid they'd be ſtole; but, I have pigs, and pigeons, and next ſummer I ſhall make a new reproach to my houſe, with a fiſtula that will give us a view of all the gibbets upon the heath; then there's a large running ditch that I'll make into a turpentine river.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Come, Nancy, let me have the ſatisfaction of ſeeing you give your hand to Dr. Laſt.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Nay, nay, no coying.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dear Sir, let me beg of you not to be ſo precipitate, but allow the gentleman and me ſufficient time to know one another, and try if our inclinations are mutual.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: My inclinations are mutual, Miſs, and not to be chang'd; for the fire of love, as I may ſay, is ſhot from your beautiful eyes into my heart; and, I cou'd ſay more—if it was not out of reſpect to the company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Perhaps, my dear, Miſs Nancy has fix'd her inclinations ſomewhere elſe, and, like a dutiful daughter, made a choice for herſelf.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: If I had, madam, it wou'd be ſuch a one as neither reaſon or honour wou'd make me aſham'd of.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: But, if I was in your papa's place, Miſs, I wou'd make you take the perſon I thought proper for your huſband, or I know what I'd do.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: O, ma'am, nobody doubts your affection; but, perhaps, you may be baulk'd in the favour you deſign me.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, but, ſtay; methinks, I make but a whimſical ſort of a figure between you both.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: The duty of a daughter, madam, is not unlimitted; and there are certain caſes to which neither law nor reaſon can make it extend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: That is to ſay, you are very willing to be married, but you are not willing your father ſhou'd have any hand in the matter.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Dr. Laſt, I beg your pardon for all this.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Let them go on, I likes to hear them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Your inſolence is inſufferable child.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I am very ſenſible, madam, you wou'd be glad to provoke me to make you ſome impertinent anſwer; but, I tell you before hand, I ſhall be careful not to give you that advantage over me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: You don't know, my dear, that you are very ſilly.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: 'Tis labour loſt, madam; I ſhall make no anſwer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: You have a ridiculous pride about you, a vain ſelf-ſufficiency, which makes you ſhocking to every body.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p:
I tell you, madam, once more, it won't do; I will preſerve my temper in ſpite of you; and, to deprive you of all hopes of ſucceeding
againſt me, I'll take myſelf out of your ſight immediately.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Heark'e, Nancy, no more words; reſolve to marry this gentleman within three days, or I'll turn you out to ſtarve in the ſtreets.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: A little impudent ſaucy minx.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: She has a purdigious deal of tongue for ſuch a young crater.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: My lamb, don't make yourſelf uneaſy about the baggage; I'll bring her to her ſenſes, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Indeed, my dear, you don't know how I'm ſhock'd at her behaviour.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Are you ſhock'd, love?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Yes, that I am to the ſoul: I thought ſhe wanted to inſinuate that I did not love you, my dear; and any thing of that kind is worſe to me than ten thouſand daggers.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: She's going to faint.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Let me feel her pulſe.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: A glaſs of water here.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: No, no, give her a glaſs of cherry brandy; I'm no friend to drenching Chriſtians bowels with water, as if they were the tripes of a brute beaſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Mr. Ailwou'd, permit me to go into my own room a little, to recover myſelf.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Do ſo, my love.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p:
And, do you hear, madam, take a dram as I bids you, a little rum and ſugar, if
you have any in the houſe; that's what I generally ſwallows, and I always finds the good effects of it.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Sir, a gentleman, that ſays he comes from your brother, Mr. Friendly, deſires to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Who is he? What wou'd he have?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I don't know—He cuts a droll figure—Here he is, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Get out of the room.

div.head: SCENE XII.
div.stage: AILWOU'D, Dr. LAST, WAG, in diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Sir, I'm your moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: By what I perceive, Sir, I have not the honour to be known to you—My name is Scower, Sir; and I come recommended by your brother, Mr. Friendly, and ſtudy the practice of phyſic.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Sir, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I obſerve you look very earneſtly at me, Sir; what age do you think I am of?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Hold, let me tell him;—What age are you of—You are about four and twenty, or thereaways.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: By the Lord, I'm above fourſcore.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: That's a damn'd lie, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Hold doctor, perhaps he has liv'd all his life upon tincture of ſage.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Sage! a fiddle! I have ſecrets myſelf that will keep me alive theſe hundred years.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: I ſuſpect this is the ſoldier that lives in the Old Bailey. You'll ſee how I'll make him expoſe himſelf. You ſay you're a doctor; who made you ſo?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Sir, I am a travelling doctor, and, at preſent, have the honour of being phyſician in ordinary to one emperor, four kings, three electors, and I don't know how many prince palantines, margraves, biſhops, and vulgar highneſſes; paſſing from town to town, from kingdom to kingdom, to find out patients worthy of my practice, and fit to exerciſe the great and noble ſecrets of my art. I ſcorn to amuſe myſelf with the little fry of common diſtempers, the trifles of rheumatiſms, ſcurvies, and megrims; give me your diſeaſes of importance, good purple fevers, good pleuriſies, with inflammations of the lungs: theſe are what pleaſe me; theſe are what I triumph over.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Ax him, can he bleed and draw teeth?—I dare to ſay, he knows nothing of chirurgery.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Have you never heard of my black powder that is taken like ſnuff, and purges by the ſmell, provided that, at the ſame time, you ſwallow three large glaſſes of laxative tiſan?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Then, its the tiſan that does it! Mark that. O! he's quite a cheat.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Let me feel your pulſe.—Come, beat as you ſhould do.— (Feeling his pulſe in a ridiculous manner; at the ſame time humming a tune.)

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why, Sir, one wou'd think you were playing upon the ſpinnet.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Even ſo, Sir; for I do not, like other phyſicians, with a watch in my hand, determine the ſtate of the pulſe by that fallible meaſurer of time.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: By a tune, which, I believe, you will allow to be a diſcovery new, and entirely my own: if the pulſe moves in concert with the minuet in Ariadne, I am ſure that the patient is well.—Let me ſee, Sir—Tol, lol, de-rol—There we dropp'd a crotchet, tol, lol, de-rol—there we mounted a minum, tol, lol, lol—and there a ſemi-demi quaver is miſſing.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: A ſemi-demi quaver!

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Stay!—Let me conſider—two bars and a half—Who is your phyſician?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Dr. Laſt.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: What! that little fellow?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Little fellow! What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Nay, gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Come, come, let us mind our buſineſs. What does he ſay is the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why, Sir, he tells me I've got the jaundice.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: He's an aſs.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Am I ſo!

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Mr. Ailwou'd look in my face. (Touching him here and there with his finger.) How do you find yourſef?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why, I don't know; I find myſelf ſome way odd.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Juſt as I ſuſpected: you have got the dropſy.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Eh! the dropſy!

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why, don't you ſee what a ſwell'd belly you have, and your eyes ſtarting out of your head?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Really, doctor, I always thought you had miſtaken my diſorder.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: He has no dropſy—he has not a ſup of water in him. Let him be tapp'd to try; I'll ſtand to his tapping.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: You are an ignoramus—Let us hear a little what are your complaints?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I have every now and then a pain in my head.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Dropſy.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Sometimes a miſt before my eyes.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Dropſy.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Sometimes a violent palpitation at my heart.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Dropſy.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: At other times, I am taken with a violent pain in my belly, as if it was the cholic.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Dropſy again.—You have a good appetite to what you eat.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Dropſy.—You love to drink a glaſs of wine.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: That's the dropſy—You take a comfortable nap after dinner?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: True, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Dropſy! dropſy! dropſy!—All dropſy.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Well, if it be, can you cure him?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: A quack like you would ſay, ay; but I ſincerely tell the gentleman at once, he's a dead man.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Then, the Lord have mercy on me!

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: That is, I mean he wou'd be dead in twenty-four hours, if I was not to help him; but I have the only remedy in the world for it.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Don't believe him; he's a cheat.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Give it to me, I'll take it, let it be what it will.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Then, obſerve, I don't deſire a braſs farthing without you're cur'd.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Look you there, doctor.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Well, don't I do the ſame?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: But, if you are cur'd, you muſt give me a hundred guineas.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: You ſhall have the money.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Its too much; I'll do it for five.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: I have been at a great deal of pains and trouble, and made many experiments, in order to find a radical cure for this diſeaſe, that ſhould be at once ſafe, cheap, and eaſy: my firſt invention was a pump; by means of which, fix'd in the belly of the patient, I meant to pump out the dropſical humour, as you wou'd water out of the hold of a ſhip; threeſcore and eleven people died under the operation.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well; what is the loſs of a few individuals, for the general good of mankind? You brought it to perfection at laſt?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: No; at laſt, I found it was impracticable; yet, I wou'd have gone on in hopes, but people grew chicken-hearted, and wou'd not let me try.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: So they well might—You ſhou'd not pump me in that manner for five thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p:
Well, Sir, my next experiment was call'd the ſoaking operation; which was contriv'd thus: I made the patient ſwallow a piece of ſpunge, faſten'd to a ſtring, which going down his throat into his ſtomach, I let lye there, till it had abſorb'd or ſoak'd up the watery humours;
and then, drew it up again, with all it contents; repeating the operation, till I had lef the body as dry as an empty decanter.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and what ſucceſs?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Why, I had a great deal better ſucceſs with this than the former; for, I think, it kill'd but four and twenty.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Well, take my advice, Mr. Ailwou'd neither be pump'd nor ſoak'd.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: The gentleman has nothing to fear; what I ſhall make uſe of upon this occaſion is, my great dryer, or eſſence infernalis.—You ſee this little phial.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Let me ſee it—and I'll make bold to taſte it too.—Don't touch it, Mr. Ailwou'd; don't touch it; its corroding ſupplement, and will throw you into a ſalvation.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Not a grain of mercury in it, upon my honour; nothing but ſimples!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Pray give the phial to me; I think I can diſtinguiſh; for I have taken a great many of theſe things.—I vow to man, it taſtes to me like ſtrong beer or porter!

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: (Aſide.) By the Lord, he has gueſs'd it.—Obſerve me, Sir, it is a tincture drawn from rat's-bane, arſenic, laudanum, verdigreaſe, copperas, with a convenient mixture of the juice of hemlock. You ſee, Sir, I deſpiſe quackery; I tell you fairly what my medicines are.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Medicines, do you call 'em?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Give it cat, dog, mouſe, rat; or, in ſhort, any creature, bypede or quadrupede, of the brute creation, they are immediately thrown into the moſt intolerable torments, ſwell like a tun, and burſt before your eyes.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: A fine medicine, indeed!

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Well, I will let you take the contents of this whole bottle; and, if it does you any more harm than ſo much new-milk, I'll give you leave to knock me down.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Knock you down!

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Nay, more; if you had infirmities from head to foot, the firſt doſe will cure you of every one of them.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, I believe it wou'd.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Tell me, Mr. Ailwou'd, what do you do with this arm?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: My arm!

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Take my advice, cut off this arm immediately.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: The deuce! Cut off my arm!

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: It is the new method of practice that I mean to introduce. Don't we prune trees of their branches, to make them more healthy? And, don't you ſee that this arm draws all the nouriſhment to itſelf, and hinders the other from thriving?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay, but I have occaſion for my arm.

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Here's an eye too, which I would have inſtantly pluck'd out, were I in your place.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Pluck out my eye!

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Don't you ſee it injures the other, and occaſions theſe miſts you complain'd of but now. Be guided by me, and have it taken away directly; you'll ſee the better with your left.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: I tell you, Mr. Ailwou'd, this is ſome cheat.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I begin to ſuſpect ſo.—Hark'e, ſirrah, who ſent you here? Are you come to murder me?

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, if you're in a paſſion, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Ay, but you ſhan't get off ſo.—Stop thief!

sp.speaker: Wag.
sp.p: Nay, then, I muſt take to my heels. (Throws his wig at Laſt, and runs off.)

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee ſuch an impudent ſcoundrel?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Do you keep the wig, we can ſwear to the wig, while I follow, and find out who he is—I'm almoſt ſure he's the ſoldier in the Old Bailey, for he has a ſpite againſt me, and employs old women to tear down my advertiſements.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ah!—I'm quite overcome, I can't ſupport myſelf any longer.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Your brother, Mr. Friendly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: How now! What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: O! Mr. Friendly, your ſervant—but I wonder you are not aſham'd to ſee my face: did you think my ſickly habit wou'd not put me out of the world ſoon enough, but you muſt join with wretches to drive me hence?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: How could you ſend me that wicked monſter, who, under the name of a doctor, wanted to give me poiſon; to cut off my arms, thruſt out my eyes, and ſo make me blind and lame?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I never ſent you any phyſician.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: No:—he pretended he came by your recommendation.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: He's ſome impoſtor—and, indeed, my dear brother, you lay yourſelf too open to the practice of ſuch fellows, who are acquainted with your weakneſs, and take advantage of it.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: My weakneſs is great, indeed, as you may ſee.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: How do you find yourſelf to-day then?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Extremely ill, indeed.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: How, extremely!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: In a condition ſo faint and feeble, that I am not able to ſtir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I have ſcarce ſtrength enough to ſpeak to you.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I'm heartily ſorry for it, brother, becauſe I came to talk to you upon a matter of conſequence; no leſs than to propoſe a match for my niece.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: (Riſing in a violent paſſion.) Brother, don't talk to me of that huſſey; ſhe's an impudent ungrateful jade; I deteſt, I renounce her, and will own no body for my friend that ſpeaks a word in her favour.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: However, brother, I'm glad to find that your ſtrength returns a little, and that you have ſtill got ſpirits enough to exert yourſelf: my viſit has done you ſo much good, at leaſt; and, to do you ſtill more, I inſiſt upon your coming with me into the garden immediately.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Into the garden!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ay; a walk there will do you good.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I have not been in the open air theſe two months.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: So much the worſe for you.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: So it is, Mr. Friendly. Do, Sir, be prevailed on by your brother.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I know I ſhall catch my death of cold.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, come then. Prudence, give me my furr'd gown.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What! to go into the garden in the middle of July?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I'll take care of myſelf, in ſpite of you all.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Get him out at any rate.—Here's your gown, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: So—Let me wrap it cloſe about me—Where are my flannel gloves?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Now, pull down my night-cap, and put on my hat.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why, brother, you're wrapt up like a Ruſſian courier, for a winter-journey into Siberia.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: You may ſay what you pleaſe.—Here, Prudence, tie a handkerchief about my neck.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Is that neceſſary too?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Come, now, brother, I'll go with you, tho' I'm ſure it will be the death of me. (Going off.)

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Well; but, Sir—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: You forget, Sir, that you can't walk without your cane.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: That's true; give it me.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.
div.stage: A Room in AILWOU'D's Houſe, with a Door in the Back Scene.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: WHERE art thou going abroad my life?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: To the Temple, my dear; to Mr. Juggle, the lawyer, to deſire him to come here and make your will, ſince you will have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: That's right, lamb, that's right—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
