sp.p: But an accident has happen'd, deareſt, which I thought it my duty to inform you of before I went.—As I paſſed by your daughter Nancy's chamber, I ſaw a young fellow there, in earneſt conference with her.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: How! with my daughter!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Yes, and I'm ſure I ſaw the ſame young fellow, a little before, talking with your brother in the parlour.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And cou'd you overhear what ſhe and the young fellow were ſaying together?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ail.
sp.p: No, ſweeteſt; but your little daughter Polly was with them.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: The child!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Aye, the child, my dear—forward enough, of her age, I aſſure you; ſhe knows as much at five, as I did at fifteen—But I dare ſwear you may get every thing out of her.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Go, pr'ythee, and ſend the little ſlut to me this inſtant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: My dear, I will—Polly! your papa wants you.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Bye, Biddy—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Do you want me, papa?—My mamma ſays you want me.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Yes, huſſey; come here;—nearer.—What do you turn away for?—Look me in the face.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Well, papa.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: So—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What, papa?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Have you nothing to tell me?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What ſhou'd I tell you?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: You know well enough, huſſey.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Not I, indeed, and upon my word.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Is this the way you do what you're bid?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Did not I order you to come and tell me immediately whatever you ſaw?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, papa.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And have you done ſo?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes; I'm come to tell you every thing I've ſeen.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Very well.—What have you ſeen to-day?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I ſaw my Lord Mayor go by in his coach.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And nothing elſe?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No; indeed, indeed.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I ſhall make you alter your tone a little, I fancy, if I fetch a rod.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Oh! dear papa.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: You baggage, you, why don't you tell me, you ſaw a man in your ſiſter's chamber?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why, my ſiſter bid me not, papa; but I'll tell you every thing.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Take care then, for I've a way of knowing all; and if you tell me a lie—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But pray, papa, don't you go and tell my ſiſter that I told you.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Never fear.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Well then, papa, there came a man into my ſiſter's chamber as I was there; I aſk'd him what he wanted, and he told me he was her Italian maſter.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Oh! the matter's out then?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: My ſiſter came in afterwards.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, and what did your ſiſter ſay?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why, firſt the man kiſs'd her.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Did he ſo?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, two or three times, but ſhe was not willing; and then ſhe ſaid to him, Go away; go away;—and ſhe ſaid, ſhe was frighten'd out of her wits—and ſhe ſaid, ſhe was afraid you wou'd come and catch her.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, and what then?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why, he wou'dn't go away.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And—What did he ſay to her?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Say?—He ſaid, I don't know how many things to her.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay; but what?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why, he ſaid this and that, and t'other;—he ſaid, he lov'd her mightily, and that ſhe was the prettieſt creature in the world.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well; and after that?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why, after that, he took her by the hand.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And after that?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: After that, he kiſs'd her again.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And after that?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: After that.—Stay;—O! after that, my mamma came, and he ran away.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And you ſaw no more?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No; indeed, and indeed, papa.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: There's ſomething, however, whiſpers in my ear that you have not told me all.—This little finger—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O that little finger's a ſtory-teller.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Have a care.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Don't believe it, papa, it fibs indeed.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, get you gone then, and remember what I have ſaid to you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, papa, yes, I'll remember.—I'm glad he didn't whip me; I was afraid he would have whip'd me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Come, now, brother, I muſt inſiſt upon it, that you will not put yourſelf in a paſſion; but ſit down here, and let me reſume the converſation which we juſt now broke off.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, come, let it be ſo.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You are to be cool now, remember.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I'll be cool.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And to anſwer me without prevarication.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Good Lord; yes, here's a terrible preamble ſure.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: How comes it then, brother, give me leave to aſk you once more, that, being in the circumſtances you are, and having no other children but two daughters, you can entertain the ſtrange deſign of marrying your eldeſt in the manner you are going to diſpoſe of her?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Pray, brother, how comes it that I am maſter of my own family, and diſpoſe of my children as I like?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Your wife, no doubt, is glad to get rid of her at any rate.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Oh! ay, now it comes—and the poor wife is to be dragg'd in; 'tis ſhe does all the miſchief, to be ſure, and all the world will have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, no, brother, we'll leave her out of the queſtion; ſhe's a good woman, that has the beſt intentions in the world for your family, is free from all manner of ſelf-intereſt, has a marvellous tenderneſs for you, and ſhews an inconceivable affection to your children, that's certain.—We'll ſay no more, therefore, of her, but return to your daughter; but, pray, let me aſk you with what view wou'd you marry her to this Dr. Laſt?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: With a view of having ſo ſkillful a phyſician as Dr. Laſt related to me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Heav'ns! Brother, how can you talk ſo?—Skillful!—I never ſaw the man; but I'm told, that, of all the quacks in town, numerous as they are, he is the moſt ignorant, as well as the moſt impudent: but, it is really ſhocking to humanity, to conſider to what a head theſe dangerous cheats are arriv'd in this great city; and, it is not leſs amazing, that people ſhou'd confide their health, their moſt valuable poſſeſſion,
to wretches they wou'd not truſt with any thing elſe: in ſhort, I know no way of putting a ſtop to their progreſs, but by an unlimited act againſt the vending of poiſons, which, I think, would very fairly comprehend them.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ha!—You have made a very fine ſpeech now.—Do you think, if the cures they perform were not wonderful, people wou'd take their medicines ſo kindly?—What has eſſence of water-dock done for the ſcurvy?—What balſam of honey, in colds and conſumptions?—The ſtomach pills for cholicky complaints?—Then, you ſenſeleſs idiot you, d'ye think his majeſty wou'd give his royal letters patent for pills, eſſences, electuaries, cordials, tinctures, quinteſſences, to poiſon his ſubjects?—But, to ſtrike you dumb at once, is not that bleſſed medicine baume de vie, in itſelf, a remedy for all diſorders under heaven?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Look at the liſt of cures—then the reaſoning's good—All diſorders ſpring from the ſtomach—Baume de vie is a ſovereign remedy for the ſtomach—and therefore cures all diſorders.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If ſo, why don't you take it, and get rid of yours?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why! why!—There's no general rule without an exception.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Come, come, brother, the truth of it is, there's nothing the matter with you at all; and I deſire no better proof of the excellency of your conſtitution than, that all the ſlops you have been taking theſe ten years have not burſt, or otherwiſe deſtroy'd you.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Here's Dr. Laſt: he is ſo good as to come on purpoſe, to adminiſter his medicine to me himſelf. Pray now, brother, behave yourſelf properly.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: AILWOU'D, FRIENDLY, and Dr. LAST, with a Vial in one Hand, and a Glaſs of Water in the other.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Ailwou'd—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Brother, with your leave.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What are you going to do now?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: To take ſome of Dr. Laſt's cordial; and, let me prevail upon you to take a glaſs too.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Do, Sir, one doſe; it's as natural to a man's conſtitution as breaſt-milk; and, if you will take it for a continency, once you are a little manured to it, it will work the moſt ſurpriſingeſt difference—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what is it?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Sir, I wou'd not tell you if you were my father; no, nor king George; but I'll ſhew you—You ſee this glaſs of New River water—it's as tranſparent as rock cryſtial.—Now, I puts twelve drops of my cordial into it—and there—its as fine aſſes-milk as ever was taſted—I vow to the Lord, there's worſe ſold for a ſhilling a pint that comes from the beaſtis themſelves.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well; I believe that's very true.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p:
I preſume, by your wig, Sir, that you belong to the law; and, if you'll put yourſelf under my care, I'll give you ſomething, for which you'll be oblig'd to me; and yet, its nothing
but the juice of a ſimple yerb; but I've tried it upon ſeveral gentlemen in your way, who, from being ſheep, as it were, have become as bold as lions.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Attend to this, brother, for its worth liſtening to.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Then its one of the beautifulleſt things upon yearth for the memory—There was a little boy, ſeven years of age, did not know one of his letters—His papa was angry, his mamma was uneaſy—They bought him the pretty books for children, letters in ſweetmeats, gingerbread, ivory, all manner of play-things to make him take to his larning, but it wou'd not do: hearing of my ſecret, they apply'd to me; I gave the child a doſe, and, will you believe it, upon the word of an honeſt man—he cou'd ſay his criſs-croſs-row in a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Now, that's very amazing! I'll make uſe of it myſelf, and begin to read immediately; for I never remember a word after the book is ſhut; and that's vexatious you know.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: And would you believe that this fine remedy was invented by my old mother?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Your mother!

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Why, ſhe knows as much of phyſic as I do; its a gift in our family; and ſhe has invented things to take ſpots out of cloaths, and iron-molds out of linen.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I long to be acquainted with her.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Well, will you ſwallow this now?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay, come, give it to me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You jeſt, ſure—Can't you be a moment without ſome naſty ſlop or another: put it off to a more convenient time, and give nature a little reſpite.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well then, this evening, Dr. Laſt, or to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, may I be ſo bold as to ax if your name aint Groggins?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, Sir, my name's Friendly.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Then, Sir, I deſire to know, Sir, what buſineſs you have to hinder me in my occupation?—I ſay, the gentleman ſhall take it now, and I warrant it will do him good.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Pr'ythee, man, what d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: I means what I ſays.—Mr. Ailwou'd, will you take it?—If you don't take it, I'll go away directly.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, do go away, Sir, we deſire it.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: O! with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Brother, you'll be the cauſe of ſome miſchief here.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What miſchief?—No, no, brother, I ſhall be the cauſe of no miſchief, but a great deal of good; and, I wiſh I cou'd drive away all the phyſic-mongers that come after you with their curſed drugs in the ſame manner, you'd live the longer for it.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Some dreadful miſchief will come of it, indeed—I muſt call him back—Dr. Laſt, Dr. Laſt.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Brother, for ſhame.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Don't talk to me, you want to ſend me to my grave—Dr. Laſt, pray come back.

sp.speaker: Laſt.
sp.p: (Fiercely to Friendly.] Did you call me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, doctor, but Mr. Ailwou'd did.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Mr. Ailwou'd, I'm not us'd politely here at all.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, it was not—

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: I have given that there thing to ladies; nay, to children that have been troubled with the worms, who never made a wry face, but lick'd their lips after it, as pleaſantly, as if it had been ſo much treacle, or ſugar-candy.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: It was not I—

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: And when I took the trouble of coming myſelf—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: 'Twas he—

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: In my own chariot—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: He was the cauſe—

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Without demanding nothing extraordinary for my trouble—I have a good mind not to marry your daughter—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I tell you it was all my brother, it was, upon my word and credit—But, give me the cordial; and, to make you amends, I'll take double the quantity.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Are you mad?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: No, he's not—I inſiſt upon his taking it for the honour of my medicine—And if you don't take a glaſs too, you ſhall hear further from me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Very well, doctor, I fear your ſword leſs than your poiſon.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: O, ay, poiſon, poiſon, we ſhall ſee whether it's poiſon.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Give it to me, doctor.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Here, Mr. Ailwou'd.

sp.speaker: Ail
sp.p: Pray now, brother, let me prevail upon you, in compliment to the doctor—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Nay, good brother, don't be abſurd.

sp.speaker: D Laſt.
sp.p: Now, I'm ſatisfied; and, I'll call upon you again in an hour.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Get me my arm'd chair here—It's inconceivable what a warmth this med'cine diffuſes all over my body.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, but brother, did not you hear Dr Laſt ſay juſt now that he was in doubt whether he wou'd marry your daughter or not; and, after ſo ſlighting an expreſſion, ſurely, you will not perſiſt in your deſign; but, let me talk to you of this gentleman who wiſhes to have my niece.

sp.speaker: Ail
sp.p: No, brother, if Dr. Laſt won't have her I'll ſend her to France, and put her in a convent; I'm ſure ſhe has an amorous inclination for ſomebody; and, to let you know, I have diſcover'd ſecret interviews in my houſe, which ſome people don't think I've diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I dare ſwear, brother, my niece has no attachment but to th • gentleman I have mentioned to you; in which caſe, you have nothing to be angry with, all tending to the honourable purpoſe of marriage.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I don't care for what you ſay, I'll ſend her over to France, I'm determined on it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: There's ſomebody you want to pleaſe, brother, by that, I doubt.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I know your meaning, Sir; you're always harping upon the ſame ſtrain.—My wife is a ſtrange hobgoblin in your eyes, brother.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Yes, brother, ſince 'tis neceſſary to be plain with you, 'tis your wife that I mean; and I can no more bear your ridiculous fondneſs for her, than that you have for phyſic; nor endure to ſee you run hand over-head into all the ſnares ſhe lays for you.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: O dear Sir, don't ſpeak ſo of my lady; ſhe's a woman that nobody can ſay any thing againſt; a woman without the leaſt grain of artifice or deſign, and loves my maſter—There's no ſaying how much ſhe loves him.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay, only aſk her how exceſſive fond ſhe is of me.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Moſt exceſſive!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: How much concern my illneſs gives her.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And the care and pains ſhe takes about me.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: —Right.—Shall we convince you now, Mr. Friendly, and ſhew you directly what a ſurpriſing affection my lady has for my maſter?—Permit me, Sir, to undeceive him, and let him ſee his miſtake.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: As how, Prudence?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Hark! my lady is juſt return'd—Do you ſtep into the next room there—ſtretch yourſelf out, and feign yourſelf dead: he may ſlip into the cloſet: I'll ſet the doors open, and you'll ſee what violent grief ſhe'll be in when I tell her the news.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Hey—hum!—I profeſs, I have a mind to take her advice—but, no; I can never bear to hear the ſhrieks and lamentations ſhe'll make over me; and yet, 'twill be a comfort to me to hear them too, to feel her virtuous tears bedew my face, and her ſweet lips kiſſing my cheeks a thouſand times, to bring me back again to life: and her—ah, verily, I'll do it; verily, I'll do it; and then, Sir, what will become of your fine ſurmiſes?—But, Prudence, art thou not afraid that her very thinking me dead will break her heart?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: To be ſure, Sir, if you ſhou'd keep her in her fright too long.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: O, let me alone for that; I'll make the experiment this very minute; this very minute.—But is there no danger in feigning one's ſelf dead?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: No, no; what danger ſhou'd there be? 'Tis only ſhutting your eyes, and ſtretching yourſelf out. [To Friendly.] Now, Sir, we ſhall ſhew you your error, and convince yow how much you have injur'd the beſt of wives. [To Ailwou'd.] 'Twill be pleaſant enough afterwards, to ſee how blank he will look—Here's my lady; quick, quick, both of you away.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh! Heav'ns! Oh! fatal misfortune! what a ſtrange accident is this!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: What's the matter, Prudence!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: [Crying.] Ah! madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: What is it? What do you mean by blubbering, pr'ythee?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: My maſter's dead, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: [Sobbing.] Ye-ye-yes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Are you ſure of it?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Too ſure, alas! No body yet knows any thing of this accident: there was not a ſoul but myſelf to help him; he ſunk down in my arms, and went off like a child—See there, madam, he lies ſtretch'd out in the next room.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Now, Heav'n be prais'd.—What a ſimpleton art thou to cry?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Cry, ma'am; why, I thought we were to cry?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: And for what, pray?—I know of no loſs he is—Was he of any uſe upon earth?—A man troubleſome to all the world; odious in his perſon; diſguſting in his manners; never without ſome filthy medicine in his mouth, or his ſtomach; continually coughing, hawking, and ſpitting; a tireſome, peeviſh, diſagreeable monſter.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: An excellent funeral ſermon, truly. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Prudence, you muſt aſſiſt me in the execution of my deſign; and you may depend upon it, I will amply reward your ſervices: ſince, by good fortune, no one is yet appris'd of this accident beſides ourſelves, let us keep his death a ſecret a few days, till I have been able to ſettle my affairs on a ſure foundation: there are papers and money, of which I wou'd poſſeſs myſelf—Nor, indeed, is it juſt, that all I have ſuffer'd with him living, ſhou'd not be rewarded by ſome advantage at his death.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: To be ſure, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: In the mean time, I'll go and ſecure his keys, for I know he has a conſiderable ſum of money in his ſcrutore, which he receiv'd yeſterday.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: AILWOU'D, FRIENDLY, PRUDENCE, and Mrs. AILWOU'D, who, going to the Door, meets her huſband, and ſcreams.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Ah! ah! ah!— [Screaming.]

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: O! devil of a help-mate, have I found you out?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Your ſervant, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Lord! my dear, I'm ſo diſappointed—ſo pleas'd, I mean, and ſo frighten'd—This wicked girl told me you were dead.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Yes, and a fine oration you pronounc'd over me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Nay, but my dear, this is the moſt unreaſonable thing; [Turning to Friendly.] ſome ſlight converſation that I have had with my maid here, which Mr. Ailwou'd takes in a wrong ſenſe; but, I dare ſwear, when he has conſider'd the matter a little, he will think differently.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Get out of my ſight, get out of my ſight.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Well, but lovey, let me explain the matter to you.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I'll never hear a word from you again as as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, if you bear yourſelf ſo haughtily, you'll find me a match for you. It is not to-day, my dear I am to learn, that your brain is full of maggots; however, you ſhall call me more than once, before I come back to you, I aſſure you.

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: AILWOU'D, FRIENDLY, PRUDENCE; and then NANCY and HARGRAVE.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Did you ever hear ſuch an impudent creature?—Od's my life, with what an air ſhe carried it!—But do'ſt think ſhe was in earneſt, Prudence?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Troth do I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Come, brother, to tell you the plain truth, Prudence devis'd this method, in order to open your eyes to your wife's perfidy—She has long deceiv'd you with a ſhew of falſe tenderneſs; but now, you ſee her in her genuine colours.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I profeſs my eyes are dazzled, and all my ſenſes confus'd; I know not what I either hear or ſee; but, in the firſt place, I renounce phyſic—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Lord! Sir, here's Miſs Nancy and Mr. Hargrave!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dear papa, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: The matter, child! I don't know, child. (Seeing Hargrave.) What brings you here, Sir?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This, brother, is the young gentleman I propoſe as a match for your daughter; and after what I have ſaid, and what has happen'd, I hope, you will no longer refuſe to liſten to his prentions.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why, really, Sir, my chief objection to you, is your total ignorance of the medicinal art; if you can think of any method to remove that—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I muſt own, Sir, I'm afraid I am rather too far advanc'd in life to make any progreſs in ſo deep and abſtracted a ſtudy.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why, with regard to the more capital branches, I grant you; but in the ſubaltern offices, I'm of a contrary opinion; ſuppoſe now you were to bind yourſelf apprentice for a year or two to ſome ſkilful apothecary; ſurely, in that time you might learn to decypher a preſcription, and make up a medicine with very few blunders.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: D'ye think ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: You might, indeed, now and then give a doſe of arſenick for ſalts; but that's an accident might happen to the oldeſt practitioner.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ah, brother, brother, what's this I hear! It was but this moment you were determin'd to renounce phyſic, and here you are talking as warmly and abſurdly about it as ever.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Eh!—It's very true, indeed, brother.—However, let it ſuffice, I give the young man my daughter without any conditions at all; and now, I'll go and get effectually rid of that other plague my wife; for I ſhall not be eaſy while we areunder the ſame roof.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If we can't cure him of his love for drugs, we have done nothing.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I doubt, Sir, that will be impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Hiſt, here comes Dr. Laſt—I'll take the opportunity of your father's abſence to have
ſome ſport with him; put on melancholly countenances, and take your cues from me.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I know what you'd be at, Sir, and I'll ſecond you.

div.head: SCENE XII.
div.stage: FRIENDLY, HARGRAVE, PRUDENCE, NANCY, Dr. LAST, and afterwards AILWOU'D.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Mr. Ailwou'd, where are you? I have brought you ſome of my eſſence of cucumber, by way of a taſte.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: O, Dr. Laſt, you're come; you're ſervant Sir, I'm glad to ſee you.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Sir, I'm oblyg'd to you—Where is Mr. Ailwou'd?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Where is he, Sir?—

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Ay; becauſe I wants to ſpeak to him.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: He's dead, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: [Burſting ridiculouſly into tears.] Oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: What's the matter, Mrs. Prudence? I warrant your maſter is only in a ſound, and I've a bottle of ſtuff in my pocket that will fetch him in a whiff.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, no more of your ſtuff.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Well then, let me go and feel his pulſe.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Nor that neither; you ſhan't go near him; but, we inſiſt upon your telling us what you gave him out of your vial juſt now?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: How! tell you my ſecret—A bookſeller offer'd me a thouſand pounds for it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
A bookſeller offer'd you a thouſand pound! That may be, Sir, but Mr. Ailwou'd
died a few minutes after you adminiſter'd it; we, therefore, take it for granted, that it has poiſon'd him; and, unleſs you prove very clearly to the contrary, we ſhall conſider you as his murderer, and treat you accordingly.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: O, don't think to humbug me ſo.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: [Enters behind.] What are they doing here?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dear Sir, have patience—Stop where you are a little, and let them go on.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Within there; ſeize this fellow.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Liberty—I'm a free-born Briton, in my native city—If any one lays a finger upon me, I'll put him into the Crown-office.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ay, but we'll put you in Newgate firſt—Carry him before a juſtice, I'll go and be witneſs.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Ay, and ſo will I.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: (In a great paſſion.) Well, but ſtay; let me go a-bit—What will you be witneſs of?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: That you poiſon'd my maſter.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: It can't be.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: We'll prove it.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: It's a fictious report; for to let you ſee the difference now—what I gave him was nothing in the world but a little chalk and vinegar; and if it cou'd do him no good, it cou'd do him no harm.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And ſo, ſirrah, this is the way you take people in; your famous cordial then is, chalk and vinegar?

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: What! Mr. Ailwou'd, aren't you dead?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p:
No, ſirrah; but no thanks to you for that; ſo get you out of my houſe, or I'll chalk
and vinegar you with a vengeance, you pretending, quacking, cheating—

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Don't ſtrike me.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I'll break every bone in your ſkin if you don't get out of my houſe.

sp.speaker: Friend,
sp.p: Nay, brother—

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: My own chariot's below.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: A cart, a wheelbarrow, for ſuch ſcoundrels.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: Don't call me out of my name.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I can't, ſirrah.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: You did, you did, and I'll make you pay for it.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Get out of my houſe.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: That's all I want—He has puſh'd me—I call you every one to witneſs—I'll ſwear to the aſſault—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Take him away.

sp.speaker: D. Laſt.
sp.p: (As they are taking him away.) I'll ſwear to the aſſault—and, if I don't get redemnification—

div.head: SCENE LAST.
div.stage: AILWOU'D, FRIENDLY, HARGRAVE, NANCY, PRUDENCE, POLLY.

sp.speaker: Polly.
sp.p: Papa! papa!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: What's the matter, my dear?

sp.speaker: Polly.
sp.p: My mamma's gone abroad, and ſays ſhe'll never come home no more; ſo ſhe won't.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: A good riddance; a good riddance.

sp.speaker: Polly.
sp.p: Lau, papa! if that isn't the man I ſaw juſt now kiſſing my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Ah! you little tell-tale.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Indeed, Prudence, but I'm no tell-tale, ſo I an't; for he kiſs'd me too, and I never ſaid a word of it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, my dear, he's to be marry'd to your ſiſter now.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Is he?—And won't you get ſomebody to marry me, papa? You've been promiſing me a huſband a great while, and I'm tired of old John the butler.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay, my dear, I dare ſwear you'll loſe no time—But, come, brother, let us now go in.—I have got rid of my wife; I have forſworn quacks and phyſic—and, I hope, I ſhall have the ſatisfaction to ſee our friends contented.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.stage: Spoken by a LITTLE GIRL of Five Years old.

lg.l: LADIES and gentlemen, they've ſent me out—
But I'm afraid to tell you what about;
Becauſe 'twere bold in me, perhaps you'll ſay,
To come to aſk you how you like the play:
Yet that's my buſineſs; nay, more free to make,
I'm come to beg you'd like it for my ſake.
The author took me in his arms juſt now,
My dear, ſays he—he kiſs'd me too I vow—
If you'll go out and make the audience clap,
I'll give you ribbons and a fine new cap:
Beſides, he promis'd me, next time he comes
Behind the ſcenes, to bring me ſugar-plumbs.
But whatſoe'er you think the play to be,
When you go home I'm ſure you'll talk of me.
Says Lady Stingo to Sir Gilbert mild,
"At FOOTE's, Sir Gilbert, have you ſeen the child!
"'Tis really a curoſity to view her:
"Our little Betſy is a mountain to her!
"Such action, ſuch a tongue—and yet I query
"If ſhe be five years old—a very fairy!"
Sir Gilbert anſwers, with a peviſh nod,
"P'ſhaw! let the little huſſy have a rod.
"There are old folks enough to play the fool:
"Children, my lady, ſhou'd be ſent to ſchool."
And ſo they ſhould, the naughty ones, no doubt,
Who'll neither books nor needle learn without:
But I am come of no ſuch idle breed;
At four years old, I could both write and read;
To be at work my fingers ſtill are itching—
Theſe flowers here are all of my own ſtitching.
But, is my prate diſliked, for after all,
I am but young, 'tis true, and ſomewhat ſmall;
And taller ladies, I muſt needs confeſs,
Might ſpeak an epilogue with more addreſs.

However, ſome few things I have to
•… ead:
Firſt, 'pon my word and credit, I'm a maid.
Will that paſs here for merit?—I don't know—
I'm a new face—which generally does ſo.
And if you want me louder, taller, bolder,
Have patience—I ſhall mend, as I g • ow older.
